--- title: "Case Study: Reducing Readmission" --- # Setting This case study describes the process of a vascular surgery practice to improve operational, financial, and clinical outcomes by reducing length of hospital stay. The practice is affiliated with an urban academic hospital centre with shared operating rooms and hospital beds with other specialties. An audit by the medical centre has demonstrated a disproportionately longer length of hospital stay in patients that underwent open lower-extremity revascularization. This has led to complaints from other specialties and patients due to cancellation and postponement of elective surgeries. The problem was confirmed by a systems survey and patient reports and the approach to quality improvement was developed using the Plan-Do-Study-Act cycle as described previously. The samples of data analysis methods presented in this case study are meant to be examples and the quality improvement process will vary depending on the practice. The case study will describe the process of using the case to use the cause and effect diagram, Pareto chart, driver diagram, and run chart to identify problems, support improvements, and monitor progress. # Problem The length of hospital stay following open lower-extremity revascularization is longer than expected undermining the quality of patient care and hospital operations. # Cause and Effect Diagram The practice manager was informed of the prolonged length of hospital stay from the hospital centre’s audit and based on other staff and patients’ complaints. To identify and confirm the problem, the manager completed a review of administrative records and consulted multiple stakeholders including patients and their families, most responsible care service, allied members of the care team (nurses, social workers, care managers), and administration. The stakeholder group were consulted to identify key causes leading to prolonged hospitalization related to materials, methods, people, environment, and equipment. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library("SixSigma") effect <- "Longer Length of Stay" causes.gr <- c("Materials", "Methods", "Equipment", "Environment", "People") causes <- vector(mode = "list", length = length(causes.gr)) causes[1] <- list(c("Unavailable Equipment", "Delayed Transportation", "Incomplete Orders")) causes[2] <- list(c("Lack of Streamlined Clinical Pathway", "Delayed Coordination of Discharge")) causes[3] <- list(c("Insufficient Home Supplies")) causes[4] <- list(c("Missed Discharge Information", "Missed Discharge Rounds", "Team Coordination")) causes[5] <- list(c("Missing Physician Order", "Heavy Workload", "Limtied Personnel")) ss.ceDiag(effect, causes.gr, causes, sub = "Possible Causes for Increased Length of Stay Following Lower-Extremity Revascularization") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](cs-readmit_files/figure-html/cause and effect-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # Pareto Chart From the cause and effect diagram, the group identified major factors including lack of a streamlined clinical pathway on the electronic medical records, missing physician orders, lack of routine discharge rounds, exacerbation of comorbidities, delayed transportation, and missing home equipment. A chart review and a systems survey were conducted to identify the frequency of the delay type in patients experiencing prolonged hospitalization. The “vital few” delay types that had the largest contribution to delayed discharge included lack of clinical pathway, missing physician orders, and lack of routine discharge rounds. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library("qcc") frequency = c(50, 25, 10, 8, 5, 2) names(frequency) = c('Clinial Pathway', 'Physician Orders', 'Discharge Rounds', 'Clinical Exacerbation', 'Transportation', 'Home Equipment') pareto.chart(frequency, main = 'Pareto Chart', col=heat.colors(length(frequency)), las = 2 ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](cs-readmit_files/figure-html/pareto-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Pareto chart analysis for frequency Frequency Cum.Freq. Percentage Cum.Percent. Clinial Pathway 50 50 50 50 Physician Orders 25 75 25 75 Discharge Rounds 10 85 10 85 Clinical Exacerbation 8 93 8 93 Transportation 5 98 5 98 Home Equipment 2 100 2 100 ``` ::: ::: # Driver Diagram The “vital few” delay types were useful in identifying the primary and associated secondary drivers. The practice manager consulted the stakeholder group to design the interventions to test each secondary driver. Each stakeholder provided valuable input into the details of the intervention. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(DiagrammeR) DiagrammeR::grViz("digraph { graph [layout = dot, rankdir = LR] node [shape = rectangle, style = filled] aim [label = 'Reduction of LOS'] pd1 [label = 'Delayed Discharge Planning'] pd2 [label = 'Delayed Postoperative Care'] sd1 [label = 'Delay in Recognizing Discharge Needs'] sd2 [label = 'Missing Physician Orders'] sd3 [label = 'Exacerbation of Comorbidities'] sd4 [label = 'Delayed Postoperative Tests and Consultations'] ci1 [label = 'Implementation of Clinical Pathway on Electronic Medical Records'] ci2 [label = 'Daily Discharge Rounds to Coordinate with Discharge Case Manager'] ci3 [label = 'Inclusion of Preoperative Consultation Recommendations in Task Items'] ci4 [label = 'Implement Streamlined Consultation and Diagnostic Test Requests as Postoperative Pathway'] aim -> {pd1 pd2} pd1 -> {sd1 sd2} pd2 -> {sd3 sd4} sd1 -> ci1 sd2 -> ci2 sd3 -> ci3 sd4 -> ci4 }") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: # Run Chart Following the implementation of an intervention/change idea, the practice manager reviewed the charts of patients that underwent open lower-extremity revascularization. The practice manager and the stakeholder group established targets of early discharge defined as discharge within 5 days postoperatively. The data on proportion of early discharge 6 months prior to the intervention were collected to evaluate the baseline performance. Following consultation with the stakeholder group, the outcome and process measures were selected including length of stay, cost, discharge summary completion within 5 days, and balancing measure including readmission was considered as a potential consequence of early discharge. +-----------------------+----------------------------------+---------------------------+ | Measure Type | Example | Where data could be found | +=======================+==================================+===========================+ | **Outcome Measure** | - Length of Stay | - Administrative data | | | | | | | - Cost | - Hospital Financials | +-----------------------+----------------------------------+---------------------------+ | **Process Measure** | - Discharge summary completion | - Direct observation | | | | | | | - Medication Reconciliation | - EMR Chart Review | +-----------------------+----------------------------------+---------------------------+ | **Structure Measure** | - Number of case managers | - HR database | +-----------------------+----------------------------------+---------------------------+ | **Balancing Measure** | - Readmission | - Registry data | +-----------------------+----------------------------------+---------------------------+ The data on proportion of early discharges were collected monthly from administrative and clinical records and plotted on the run chart to assess for improvements and monitor progress. The first intervention led to an improved outcome and the implementation and the process of the intervention were reassessed and further improved based on stakeholder feedback. Following additional modifications to the initial intervention, the practice saw a greater improvement in the proportion of early discharge ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library("qicharts2") y <- c(25, 24, 27, 24, 28, 30, 35, 38, 37, 40, 38, 40) n <- c(55, 57, 55, 50, 57, 52, 54, 51, 52, 53, 52, 50) date <- seq(as.Date("2023/01/01"), as.Date("2023/12/31"), by = "months") notes <- NA notes[6] <- "Intervention" qic (y, n, x = date, ylab = "Proportion of Early Discharge", xlab = "Month", notes = notes) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](cs-readmit_files/figure-html/run chart-1.png){width=672} ::: :::
